verses.text: Watching over wealth causes sleeplessness, and concern for it drives away sleep.
verses.comment: Wisdom literature repeatedly warns against anxious striving for wealth; cross-reference to Proverbs and Psalms illustrates this enduring biblical theme.

verses.text: Wakeful anxiety keeps sleep from coming, and a severe illness drives away slumber.
verses.comment: This verse reflects ancient wisdom’s insight into how worry and illness disrupt peace, paralleling Proverbs 12:25 about anxiety weighing the heart.

verses.text: The rich person toils to gather wealth, and when he rests, he enjoys his delicacies.
verses.comment: Contrasting rich and poor, the text observes that wealth provides comfort, highlighting how possessions can ease material burdens but may not solve deeper spiritual concerns.

verses.text: The poor person toils for a meager living, and if ever he rests, he finds himself in need.
verses.comment: The plight of the poor, who labor for mere survival and remain vulnerable even in rest, recalls the social justice themes of Proverbs 13:23.

verses.text: A lover of money will not be declared innocent; those who chase after it will be caught by its snares.
verses.comment: Paul says the love of money is a root of all evils. True innocence is found in uprightness and a rightly ordered love.

verses.text: Many have been brought low by gold, and its destruction was plain to see.
verses.comment: The golden calf incident points to how wealth can turn hearts away from God. Biblical revelation consistently warns against idolatry and greed.

verses.text: It is a snare for those who are obsessed with it, and all foolish are taken captive by it.
verses.comment: Riches easily enthrall the unwary mind. Throughout Scripture, wisdom is contrasted with folly, and detachment is commended.

verses.text: Blessed is the rich person found without blemish, who does not go after gold without limit.
verses.comment: Here, the rare virtue of wealth without greed is praised; reminiscent of Jesus' challenge to store up treasure in heaven.

verses.text: Who is he, that we may praise him? For he has done wonders among his people.
verses.comment: There is honor in using wealth righteously—charity is remembered before God, as with the woman who anointed Jesus.

verses.text: Who has been tested by it and found perfect? Let this be his reason to boast. Who had power to transgress but did not, and to do evil yet did not do it?
verses.comment: True virtue is seen in resisting temptation despite the power to sin; this echoes Job's integrity under trial (Job 1:22) and the praise of restraint.

verses.text: His prosperity will be established, and the assembly will proclaim his acts of charity.
verses.comment: Righteous conduct receives both divine blessing and communal recognition, linking prosperity with charity as in Psalm 112:9.

verses.text: When you sit at a great table, do not be greedy, nor say, 'There is much food here!'
verses.comment: Self-restraint at feasts signals wisdom, as Jesus teaches humility at banquets in Luke. Moderation reflects inner freedom.

verses.text: Remember that greedy eyes are evil. What comes worse than such an eye? It weeps with every mouthful.
verses.comment: Greed blinds the soul to goodness. Jesus lists evil eye among defilements that come from the heart. Purification is both moral and spiritual.

verses.text: Do not reach out your hand, wherever it looks, nor rush upon the dish.
verses.comment: Curbing selfish impulses during communal meals reflects Christ's example in the Last Supper, inviting us to deep fellowship.

verses.text: Consider your neighbor’s needs as your own, and be thoughtful in every matter.
verses.comment: Echoes the Golden Rule and Old Testament law—love of neighbor is at the heart of God’s law and fulfilled in Christ’s teaching.

verses.text: Eat like a human being, not like one who devours excessively; moderation in eating brings health.
verses.comment: Temperance is highlighted as a virtue that promotes both body and soul. Disciplining appetites reflects mastery, as Paul writes.

verses.text: Be the first to stop, as is proper, and do not be greedy, so you do not give offense.
verses.comment: Moderation in eating is a mark of self-control and social grace, cautioning against greed to avoid offense, akin to Proverbs 25:16.

verses.text: If you are seated among many, do not help yourself before they do.
verses.comment: Practicing humility at communal meals showcases respect for others, discouraging selfishness and promoting unity, consistent with Luke 14:7-10.

verses.text: How little is enough for a well-disciplined person! He does not struggle to breathe when in bed.
verses.comment: Discipline in consumption brings bodily well-being, a principle found in Proverbs 23:20-21 against overindulgence.

verses.text: Healthy sleep comes from moderate eating; he rises early and feels refreshed. Sleeplessness, nausea, and colic attend the glutton.
verses.comment: The link between moderation and restful sleep highlights the physical consequences of gluttony, underscoring holistic wisdom.

verses.text: If you are overfilled with food, rise up and vomit, and you will find relief.
verses.comment: A practical and vivid proverb, suggesting that relief from excess is found in restraint or even purging, accentuating the dangers of overindulgence.

verses.text: Listen to me, my child, and do not disregard my words, and in the end you will come to understand. In everything you do be moderate, and no sickness will overtake you.
verses.comment: The appeal to moderation as a safeguard for health and spiritual flourishing reflects central wisdom literature (see Proverbs 25:27).

verses.text: People bless the one who is generous with food, and his testimony is reliable.
verses.comment: Generosity at table fosters community and trust, aligning with Old Testament hospitality norms and Jesus’ emphasis on sharing meals (Luke 14:13-14).

verses.text: The city complains about the one who is stingy with food, and their testimony of his stinginess is true.
verses.comment: Stinginess is publicly reproved, with communal opinion acting as a moral barometer, reminiscent of Proverbs 28:27.

verses.text: Do not try to prove your strength by drinking wine, for wine has destroyed many.
verses.comment: The warning against proving one’s worth through drinking alludes to the destructive power of alcohol and pride, cf. Proverbs 20:1.

verses.text: As a furnace tests the work of the smith, so wine tests hearts in the heat of argument.
verses.comment: Wine reveals true character, especially amid strife, much like fire tests metal—suggesting trial’s role in exposing the heart.

verses.text: Wine is the very life for human beings if taken in moderation. What is life to one who is without wine? It was made to bring joy to people.
verses.comment: Wine’s benefits, when enjoyed moderately, affirm its positive role in hospitality and joy, as seen in Psalm 104:15.

verses.text: Wine drunk at the proper time and in moderation brings joy to heart and gladness to soul.
verses.comment: Moderate, timely use of wine enhances celebration and well-being, continuing the tradition of feasting in biblical festivals.

verses.text: Wine drunk to excess breeds bitterness of spirit, leading to quarrels and stumbling.
verses.comment: Overindulgence in wine destroys harmony and causes relational and personal strife, echoing warnings in Proverbs 23:29-35.

verses.text: Drunkenness increases the anger of a fool to his own harm, diminishing his strength and multiplying wounds.
verses.comment: Drunkenness is condemned for leading to violence and self-harm, consistent with biblical cautions against folly (Ephesians 5:18).

verses.text: Do not reprove your neighbor at a banquet of wine, nor despise him in his merrymaking; speak no word of reproach to him, and do not distress him with demands.
verses.comment: Respecting a neighbor’s joy and avoiding reproach at feasts upholds peace and kindness, echoing wisdom about gracious speech (Proverbs 25:11).
